intro: Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. pannonica, commonly known as the Pannonian ash, is a deciduous tree native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 15–25 meters, featuring a straight trunk and a rounded crown. The leaves are opposite, lanceolate, and have a smooth margin, with a dark green upper surface and a lighter underside. Its flowers are small and yellowish-green, appearing in drooping clusters, and it produces small, winged samaras as its fruit. This subspecies is adapted to a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, fertile ground.
